title: The difference between Garamond, Garamond Premier Pro and Adobe Garamond Pro?
content:
So I was looking through my font list and I found that I have 3 separate versions of Garamond. I have [Garamond](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312204039/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Garamond), Garamond Premier Pro, and Adobe Garamond Pro.

Being rather new to the world of typography I was wondering what the difference(s) between them was. So I put the three styles next to each other and I noticed some differences in stroke weight, stress, density and so on but I figured I would see if there was anyone on here that could explain to me what is so different about the three.  
Perhaps its a stupid question.
author: Cody

comments.content: There are literally scores of different digitizations and renditions of Garamond's original metal typefaces. I am not sure which foundry's is your "Garamond" (you might find out by looking at its info in FontExplorer X) but Adobe Garamond and Garamond Premier have very distinct differences which you can learn about at [Adobe](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312204039/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Adobe)'s website.

Ahh, thank you much, It was really the difference between Adobe Garamond pro and Garamond Premier Pro that I was wondering about. The Garamond I have had some very clear differences from the other two but adobe and Premier are quite similar.

You might also look at [this quick review of some of the differences.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312204039/http:/www.fonts.com/NR/rdonlyres/EF8A90A6-66C8-40D5-95F8-AEF62BB05705/0/ILGaramond.pdf) There's a lot there to discover if you really are interested.

Since the second two are Adobe I will assume you are referring to Adobe versions. There might be some slight differences contour shapes between the early Adobe versions and the Pro and Premium versions. The main difference is the number of extras that the newer versions contain. Premium was included with the CS3 version of creative suite and has a very large number of glyphs including a lot of ornaments. The Pro version is a bit smaller than the Premium and that is what now ships with CS4.

Yikes, this is completely wrong. The two Adobe families mentioned in the OP are Garamond Premier Pro and Adobe Garamond Pro. Adobe Garamond was one of the first Adobe Originals, designed by Robert Slimbach and released in 1989. It was later converted to OpenType and renamed Adobe Garamond Pro.

Garamond Premier Pro is a completely separate Garamond revival, also by Robert Slimbach. It is less regularized (Adobe Garamond had to be designed to accommodate less powerful software and hardware of its day) and has four optical sizes. Garamond Premier Pro also has Greek and Cyrillic.

There is no "Premium" version. They both support CE languages, so they both have the "Pro" suffix.
